newsitem.title: SWITZERLAND: Red Cross to axe 100 jobs in Geneva.
newsitem.headline: Red Cross to axe 100 jobs in Geneva.

text.p: The Swiss-run International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC) said on Thursday it was axing some 100 jobs at its Geneva headquarters.
Spokeswoman Doris Pfister said the cuts were to reduce costs and were part of a restructuring to help the agency concentrate more on field work.
The reduction of the ICRC's Geneva workforce by almost one-sixth will be the first sizeable job cut ever made by the agency, which helps victims of conflicts around the world.
The cuts will be carried out gradually over the next few years. The ICRC has 670 employees in Geneva and another 900 in the field.
The ICRC had a deficit of 20 million Swiss francs ($13 million) in 1996. Its biggest contributor is the United States which covers some 20 percent of its annual budget.
The agency lost six Western employees in Chechnya and three in Burundi in terrorist attacks in 1996, the highest number of such deaths in its 133-year history.
